content.question: The figure above shows the graphs of the polar curves <math alttext="r equals, 2 times the sine squared of theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>sin</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.15em"></mspace><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="r equals, 4 times the sine squared of theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>sin</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.15em"></mspace><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to theta, less than or equal to pi" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following integrals gives the area of the region bounded between the two polar curves?

choices.label: <math alttext="the integral from, 0 to pi, of, the sine squared of theta, d theta" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>

<math alttext="the integral from, 0 to pi, of, 2 times the sine squared of theta, d theta" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow></msubsup><mn>2</mn><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>

<math alttext="the integral from, 0 to pi, of, 2 times the sine to the fourth power, of theta, d theta" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow></msubsup><mn>2</mn><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>

<math alttext="the integral from, 0 to pi, of, 6 times the sine to the fourth power, of theta, d theta" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow></msubsup><mn>6</mn><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="the integral from, 0 to pi, of, 6 times the sine to the fourth power, of theta, d theta" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow></msubsup><mn>6</mn><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.9: (BC ONLY) Finding the Area of the Region Bounded by Two Polar Curves

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
